title: Introduction to Tableau Desktop
headline: This free online course will teach you to explore and analyse data for meaningful visualisation and decision-making.
description: You will acquire the in-demand data analytics skills in this free online course. Tableau Desktop is data visualisation software that helps you explore and understand data. You will learn to sort and filter data and use multiple data sources in addition to adding and selecting the chart types. This course is helpful for those working with data and looking for management or decision-making positions in modern data-driven organisations.

courseDescription:
Imagine if you have to go through a report of seventy-five pages with five tables and many long paragraphs of text. Compare this with another one with fewer tables and charts with more colourful legends, labels and shorter text sections. The second report will have vastly more appeal for most of us because it will be easier and faster to read and understand due to the visuals. Tableau Desktop is a modern data visualisation platform. Its users can discover new business perspectives and create views with significant impact. In this online course, you will learn the basics of Tableau Desktop, what is it used for and whether you can use it for free. You will research its scope, interface and significant functions. We have defined important terminologies and explained them clearly in the videos so that you gain familiarity and comfort with using this platform.

The first module explores the type of data structures used with Tableau. How do you organise data in Tableau? What type of data sources can Tableau connect? You will learn how to rename fields and change data types in addition to sorting and filtering connection types. Tableau Desktop enables you to connect to multiple data sources like MS Excel, CSV files and Google Analytics, to name a few. You will learn to create workbooks and dashboards to publish on a server or online. Next, you will explore the Tableau workspace. What are its properties and how do you add a chart? Discover how to bring data to life by understanding the basics of creating a new view on Tableau. There are four ways to do this using different data types to create separate charts. Become familiar with all these concepts and facts as you progress through the course.

Finally, you will learn the importance of selecting the correct type of charts to create visuals. The final section provides answers relating to choosing the right charts for your data and data visualisation, gaining an in-depth insight into the Tableau chart types. Then you will learn to build them from scratch, which will complete your basic training for working on a data visualisation platform. Tableau Desktop is one of the essential skills for those looking to work in data analytics. This area is growing and in demand as more and more businesses rely on big data for business decisions. Enrol now to take advantage of this free course and learn an essential skill in your own time.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Tableau Desktop is a flexible, data visualisation software, which helps you to build effective calculations, insightful views, and dashboards. In this module, you will get introduced to this software and explore its interface. You will learn about the role of business intelligence and what type of data structures should be used with this tool.
topics: Learning Outcomes: Introducing and Exploring Tableau
Lesson Summary: Introducing and Exploring Tableau

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Tableau Desktop helps the users to identify patterns and trends and build forecasts for business activities. In this module, you will learn to bring data to life by creating meaningful views. You will learn about combining multiple data connections along with the scope and uses of different types of charts to answer the management questions.
topics: Learning Outcomes: Bringing Data to Life
Lesson Summary: Bringing Data to Life

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • Tableau is used to apply modern business intelligence to the systems of modern industries. It is one of the fastest-growing data visualisation tools as it helps simplify raw data to an easily understandable format.
    • Tableau has a flexible front-end and intuitive interface that visually expresses data by translating drag-and-drop actions into data queries.
    • Tableau product suite contains several pieces of software which can be classified into the following two categories–Developer tools, Sharing tools.
    • Tableau developer tools are Tableau Desktop, Tableau Public, Tableau Prep. Tableau sharing tools are Tableau Reader, Tableau Server, Tableau Online, Tableau Mobile.
    • Business intelligence refers to the processes and technologies leveraged by the enterprises to collect, integrate, analyse and present pertinent business information in a format that is easy to interpret.
    • Business intelligence provides historical, current and predictive views of the business operations and turns raw data into actionable insights.
    • The start page of Tableau Public has three different panes– Connect, Open, and Discover.
    • The Discover pane has links to popular views in Tableau Public. This pane has links to training videos to hone your Tableau skills and the Resource section in this pane lets you be informed from blogs and news.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • To create a new view, start with a question that will be answered by your visualisation. There are four ways to create a view in Tableau Desktop– (a) Drag fields from pane to shelves (b) Double-click fields in data pane (c) Select fields and use 'Show Me' (d) Drop field here.
    • Shelf placement and type of fields directly affect the output visualisation.
    • Each type of data creates a different chart in Tableau. (a) A discrete dimension creates categories or groups of the values (b) A continuous dimension creates an axis in the visualisation (c) A discrete measure is visualised as labels or text (d) A continuous measure creates a numeric axis in the view.
    • The 'Marks Card' provides you with control over how the points or marks will look like in a view. It can apply different properties to the marks of the graph which adds additional meaning and detail.
    • Blends query each data source independently while combining multiple data connections. The results are aggregated to the appropriate level and then presented visually together in the view.
    • When data blending, data sources can be identified as either a primary data source or a secondary data source.
    • As opposed to a blend, a join combines the data first before applying an aggregation.
    • The Blend is established individually on every sheet and can never be published. You need to publish the data sources separately and then blend the published data source.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • To create a new view, start with a question that will be answered by your visualisation. There are four ways to create a view in Tableau Desktop– (a) Drag fields from pane to shelves (b) Double-click fields in data pane (c) Select fields and use 'Show Me' (d) Drop field here.
    • Shelf placement and type of fields directly affect the output visualisation.
    • Each type of data creates a different chart in Tableau. (a) A discrete dimension creates categories or groups of the values (b) A continuous dimension creates an axis in the visualisation (c) A discrete measure is visualised as labels or text (d) A continuous measure creates a numeric axis in the view.
    • The 'Marks Card' provides you with control over how the points or marks will look like in a view. It can apply different properties to the marks of the graph which adds additional meaning and detail.
    • Blends query each data source independently while combining multiple data connections. The results are aggregated to the appropriate level and then presented visually together in the view.
    • When data blending, data sources can be identified as either a primary data source or a secondary data source.
    • As opposed to a blend, a join combines the data first before applying an aggregation.
    • The Blend is established individually on every sheet and can never be published. You need to publish the data sources separately and then blend the published data source.
